Graphical abstract Flowerlike birnessite MnO2 was tightly cohered via NiMnO3 interphase on 3-dimensional macroporous Ni foam, and it showed good performance on soot oxidation with excellent durability. K+ stabilized in the form of composites effectively activated O2 thus improved capabilities. The soot particulates emitted from diesel engines have been ultimately evidenced cancerogenic and successive rigorous emission legislations have been approved in many countries. Monolithic metal-based purification materials are able to tackle the harsh working conditions. Hence, monolithic birnessite MnO2/Ni foam catalysts were facilely synthesized via a hydrothermal route and characterized by XRD, Raman spectroscopy, SEM, HRSTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, et al. The coating weights are in proportion to hydrothermal temperatures. And the catalyst synthesized at 160 °C displays the lowest T50 (418 °C) with the coating exfoliation rates of only 0.45 ± 0.11 wt. %. Porous Ni substrates tightly covered with a layer of crosslinked flowerlike birnessite MnO2 coating would provide many available sites capturing soot particulates. The interphase NiMnO3 between nanoflowers and Ni substrate could intensify nanoflowers against exfoliation, and inhibit transformation into disordered nanorods. Potassium in the birnessite may activate gas O2 effectively forming active oxygen species and improve the redox properties. Moreover, nickel dopants inhibit K+ thermal evaporation and water dissolution via strengthening KO bonds, thus endowing good reusability. This candidate is likely a promising monolithic catalyst purifying the real diesel exhaust. And the method will be employed to synthesize novel monolithic metallic catalysts for other catalytic applications. Keywords Monolithic catalysts Birnessite MnO2 Interphase intensification Soot removal Exfoliation 1 Introduction The industry of diesel engines has encountered the most serious crisis during the past few years due to carcinogenic exhaust [1]. And more stringent emission legislations have been approved in succession. Four hazardous componentsCO, NOx, VOCs (Volatile Organic Compounds) and soot exist in the exhaust, among which soot has been evidenced the most cancerogenic [2]. Currently, diesel particulate filters (DPFs) of passive regeneration are widely employed owing to low cost as well as valid soot abatement. However, cordierites (2MgO·2Al2O3·5SiO2) or SiC filters suffer from the bump and thermal shock under severe working conditions [3]. So, metallic foam-based filters have been developed due to superior thermal conductivity, thinner walls and shock resistance [4]. But the coatings on smooth metal surface are weakly attached, which would abscise and decrease soot trapping efficiency [5,6]. Ulla and his coworkers have done a lot of meaningful work on this front [7,8]. However, the complicate procedures usually include roughening substrates, immersing binders and incorporating active species coatings. On the other side of the coin, metal foams are also employed in the field of energy with novel preparation routes [9–12]. And Ni foam is employed in our research because the three dimensionally micro-sized pores will benefit for soot delivery with negligible pressure drop [13,14]. In our previous work, a series of three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) catalysts showed excellent performance as a result of abundant contact points, which promoted the heterogeneous gas-solid-solid soot oxidation [15–17]. Besides, mesoporous MnO2 composites also displayed high activity toward soot oxidation for abundant oxygen vacancies and strong interaction between MnO2 and transition metal oxides (TMOs) [18]. Manganese-based materials have been widely applied for soot combustion, CO and VOCs oxidation, etc [19–21]. Specifically, Wagloehner et al. reported soot oxidation on bare manganeses including MnO2, Mn2O3, Mn3O4 and found nanosized Mn3O4 originating from flame spray pyrolysis (FSP-Mn3O4) the best activity and good hydrothermal stability [22]. Cheng et al. investigated the morphology of cubic, truncated octahedral and octahedral α-Mn2O3. Cubic α-Mn2O3 is proved to be best due to (100) facets, on which more low-coordinated surface oxygen sites facilitate oxygen activation, thus improving soot oxidation [23]. Potassium-promoted manganeses composites, especially birnessite MnO2, would further catalyze soot combustion. Birnessite MnO2 consists of [MnO6] layers and charge balance ions such as K+, Na+ or transition ions [24]. An et al. investigated the effect of alkali dopants into oxides and reported transmission metal ions could inhabit potassium loss [25]. Similarly, Legutko et al. reported it would be more effective when K+ was doped in the bulk rather than on the surface because high potassium loading generated birnessite and remarkably decreased soot oxidation temperature by 150 °C [26,27]. A. Bueno-López and his coworkers synthesized birnessite via calcining KMnO4 and thought it a promising candidate in practical application compared with other manganese oxides [28,29]. K+ would stabilize the layer structure of birnessite MnO2 while [MnO6] layers improve the stability of potassium species [30]. However, all these powdered catalysts have to be overlaid on the metal filters using mostly aluminum sols as binders even though the binders may decrease activities [31]. In addition, in the catalyst-coated filters, it will greatly improve the contact chances between catalysts and soot by dispersing nano-sized catalysts on the internal surface of filters, which will surely improve the regeneration performance [32,33]. Hence, based on our previous work, it seems promising to prepare firm birnessite MnO2 coating on Ni foam without adding binders. And the reaction between KMnO4 and Ni foam may intensify the coating stability due to new generated interphase. In this paper, we synthesized a battery of monolithic birnessite MnO2/Ni foam catalysts through a facile hydrothermal method based on the redox reaction between KMnO4 and Ni foam. The specimens display strong adhesion and good performance toward soot combustion. The contact conditions between birnessite MnO2 coatings and soot are obviously improved [32,33]. It is the interphases NiMnO3 or Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 tightly combining the substrate with active components, and the crosslinked flowerlike morphology adding contact points that accelerate soot removal. Potassium species can be also effectively stabilized in the form of composites against thermal evaporation and water corrosion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of monolithic catalysts Pure Ni foam (130 PPI, 280 g/m2, Kunshan Jiasheng Electronics Co., Ltd., China) was cut into 3 × 7 cm2 (∼0.588 g) firstly. Then it was ultrasonically cleaned with acetone, ethanol, 0.2 M HCl solution and deionized water for 10 min respectively. At the same time, 0.6320 g KMnO4 (AR, Shanghai Lingfeng Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) was dissolved into 80.0 mL deionized water (0.050 mol·L−1) and then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Then, the cleaned Ni foam was dipped vertically into the solution and the hydrothermal reaction was conducted at 100, 120 and 160 °C for 24 h separately. After cooled down to room temperature, the black foam was washed several times and dried at 70 °C. Catalysts were obtained after calcination at 550 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1. Besides, the sample synthesized at 160 °C was also calcined at 700 °C to investigate the thermal stability. The coating contents on Ni foams were calculated using the net weight increasements after hydrothermal reaction. For convenience, the catalysts prepared at 100, 120 and 160 °C were recorded as A, B, C while the samples calcined at 700 °C was denoted as D. 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was conducted on a Smartlab TM 9 kW (Rigaku, Japan) utilizing nickel-filtered Cu Kα source (λ = 0.15418 nm). The data were collected from 10 to 80° at a step of 0.02° and speed of 10°∙min−1. The phase identifications were calibrated using pure Ni (JCPDS#89-7128) to eliminate errors due to minor difference on species heights. N2 isothermal physisorption was operated on a BELSORP MINI (MicrotracBEL, Japan) at 77 K. Prior to the physisorptions, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 3 h at the pressure below 1 kPa. The Raman spectrum was obtained on a micro confocal Raman system (LabRam HR, HORIBA) equipped with an Ar-Kr laser, by exciting at 514 nm. The morphology of the samples was observed on a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan) and a high-resolution scanning transmission electron microscope (HRSTEM, Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN, USA) with an accelerating voltage of 300 keV. Before the TEM test, the samples were ultrasonically treated for at least 40 min in anhydrous alcohol. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on an ESCALAB 250X (ThermoFisher Scientific, USA) equipped with an Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation at the pressure below 5 × 10−10 mbar. All peaks were calibrated by C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV, and the spectra were fitted using XPSPEAK41 program by curve fitting with Lorentz-Gaussian function after subtracting Shirley-type backgrounds. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was tested on a chemical adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics Auto Chem Ⅱ 2920). The sample was firstly pressured and cut into ∼2 × 2 mm2 slices and then 30.0 mg of the catalogue was pretreated under an Ar atmosphere at 200 °C for 2 h. After cooled down to 100 °C, 10% H2/Ar flow (50 mL∙min−1) was passed through with the temperature ramped to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The H2 consumption was recorded online by a TCD and quantified by standard CuO sample. 2.3 Catalytic performance 2.3.1 Soot TPO A self-capture contact mode (SCCM) representing loose contact between soot and catalysts was employed in this paper [13,34]. Briefly, 5.0 mg soot (Printex U, Degussa) was ultrasonically dispersed in 10.0 mL absolute ethanol for 30 min. and then dropped on the monolithic catalysts. After dried at 60 °C for 2 h, the process was repeated two times until the mass ratio of soot to active components was about 1:10. Then, the monolithic mixture was sandwiched in the center of a cylindrical quartz tube (i. d. = 8 mm, length = 52 cm) with silica wool. The catalyst bed was pretreated at 180 °C for 30 min in high-purity N2 and then heated at a rate of 5 °C min−1 until 700 °C. The 20 vol. % O2/N2 influent gas rate was controlled by a mass flow meter at 100 mL∙min−1 (STP) while the compositions of effluent gas were analyzed by a non-dispersive Infrared analyzer (Infralyt 50). The T10, T50, T90 representing 10%, 50%, 90% soot conversion and S C O 2 m (CO2/(CO + CO2) at the Tm) were taken as the indices of performance. All the tests were conducted three times and the average values were calculated. 2.3.2 Moisture effect The effect of water vapor on soot oxidation was evaluated by bubbling 6 vol. % H2O into the influent gas in 2.3.1. A drying column filled with anhydrous CaCl2 and CuSO4 was set before the analyzer. The signal delay on drying column was 5 °C and was subtracted in data processing. 2.3.3 Reusability evaluation Sample C was repeatedly tested via soot oxidation both under 100 mL∙min−1 20 vol. % O2 and 6 vol. % H2O + 20 vol. % O2 conditions for 5 times to evaluate the reusability. The reactions were performed in a quartz tube (i. d. = 18 mm, length = 52 cm) where the large-sized sample could be evaluated directly. 2.4 Adherence test The adherence state of the coating on C was tested via exposing it to ultrasonic treatment at 25 ± 2 °C. Three specimens were immersed in deionized water and then placed in an ultrasonic bath (KQ32000E, 40 kHz, 150 W) for 60 min. Then, the samples were dried at 110 °C for 2 h. The average weight changes before and after the treatments were recorded to evaluate the adhesion state. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure properties The wide-angle XRD data, which have been calibrated using the strong peaks of pure Ni substrates (*, JCPDS#89-7128, Fm-3 m), are illustrated in Fig. 1 a. The peak heights of NiO species (#, JCPDS#71-1179, Fm-3 m) are similar in A, B and C, yet increase slightly in D. As for the weak peaks enlarged in Fig. 1b, three species can be detected. No peak in A and B implies high dispersion or small quantity below the detection limit. In C and D catalysts, the peaks at 12.64, 25.24° are birnessite MnO2 (&, JCPDS#80-1098, C2/m) while the peak at 33.71° should be ascribed to NiMnO3 (%, JCPDS#75-2089, R-3) [28,29]. K+ and H2O molecules may balance the [MnO6] layer structure of birnessite MnO2 and the right shift of birnessite MnO2 peaks could be resulted from the moisture escape after calcination, left only K+ between the layers [24]. Ni2+ and Ni3+ dopants aftermentioned also account for the right shift. However, no further phase transformation from birnessite MnO2 to α-MnO2 occurs as reference reported where α-MnO2 is generated above 400 °C [18]. Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 (♥, JCPDS#89-5878, Fm-3 m) emerges in D as a result of further solid state reactions between birnessite MnO2 and Ni substrate or NiO at higher temperature [35]. NiMnO3 or Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 interphase would stabilize birnessite MnO2 and inhabit the phase transformation. Since minor active components are synthesized on Ni substrate via the hydrothermal route. Micro confocal Raman spectroscopy is employed due to surface sensitivity and the depth of investigation is exactly several hundred nanometers [24,36]. Fig. 2 displays the Raman spectra, where it is noteworthy that resonance enhancement phenomenon, which has been rarely reported on Mn-based catalysts, could be observed on A, B and C under the exciting source of 514 nm [37,38]. The main peaks at 587 cm−1 are two orders of magnitude higher than those in reference and might be ascribed to the Herzberg-Teller vibrionic coupling within the local surface structures [39]. This enhancement remarkably decreases in D, due to possible structure degradation. As a supplement of XRD results, the Raman shifts at 500 (TO), 587 (LO) and 626 cm−1 are obviously birnessite MnO2, while peaks at 1073 and 1170 cm−1 are LO + TO and 2LO [24]. The peaks at 356 and 649 cm−1 might be NiMnO3, proving unambiguously the existence of interphases and this would account for the excellent mechanical combination in the catalysts [40,41]. The interconnected macropores of monolithic Ni foam are benefit for reactants transmission and products delivery; in addition the meso/micro structures play an important role on surface reactions. Fig. 3 shows the N2 isothermal physisorption patterns of the catalysts while the specific surface areas (SSA) and pore sizes are listed in Table 1 . All the species display very small SSA, of which the largest one is C—only 5.6 m2 g−1. Besides, the pore volumes and pore sizes show the same trend due to the small proportions of active components since these values of the Ni substrate are negligible. As displayed in Table 1, birnessite MnO2 accounts for 2.01 wt. %, 4.30 wt. % in A and B, but 9.55 wt. %, 9.61 wt. % in C and D. Hence, the role of SSA on soot oxidation might be not fatal since the size of soot particulate is about 25 nm and soot oxidation processes at the three-phase boundary [42]. 3.2 Morphology researches SEM images of the catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 4 . Pristine Ni foam (Fig. 4a) has developed macropores around 300 μm, which endues effective mass and heat transfer properties as reported elsewhere [11]. The smooth surface of metal Ni (insert in Fig. 4a) would be decorated with a curious layer of birnessite MnO2 nanoflakes after hydrothermal reaction. From Fig. 4b–d it is obvious that the large-scale nanoflakes grow directly as hydrothermal temperatures. Specifically, in Fig. 4b there are only short rods and few flakes leaning to the substrate with mean length of 150 nm, which then totally transfer into perpendicular crosslinked flakes in Fig. 4c. The average distance between these adjacent flakes is about 230 nm and this may provide effective accessible points for soot particulates, as our previous work and references reported [15,43]. The nanoflakes would develop further in Fig. 4d, as evidenced by the hierarchical pores on the flakes and the enlarged SSA values. These multistage pore structures would disappear after calcination at 700 °C in Fig. 4e [44]. The thin flakes would collapse, amalgamate and react with Ni substrate until nanobelts. This is in consistent with XRD results that Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 rather than NiMnO3 emerges. Fig. 1f clearly shows the sandwich structure of C catalyst including Ni substrate, NiO or NiMnO3 interphases and birnessite MnO2 coating. Except the meaningful crosslinked nanoflakes, the combination between active components and Ni substrate is vital to the catalytic performance [45–47]. In our previous work and references, the shapes of products synthesized from KMnO4 solution decomposition are nanoflowers or nanoflakes, which then transform into nanorods through a rolling mechanism during calcination (Fig. S1a and b, Supporting Information) [18,48]. However, all the samples in this paper do not undergo this transformation as shown in Fig. S1c. Two possible reasons might account for this. Firstly, the interphases NiMnO3 and Ni6.8Mn0.6O8, which firmly bind birnessite MnO2 and Ni substrate, might inhabit the transformation via this oriented structure. And the other are nickel dopants in the nanoflakes, as following EDS and XPS evidenced. The oxidation of pure Ni would form NiO nanoflakes like that of birnessite MnO2 [12]. It is likely the consistency between Ni substrate and birnessite MnO2 determines the morphology [49]. This sandwich structure obviously enhances the mechanical strength as that in Fe-Cr-Al alloys where the coating is immobilized via Al2O3 whiskers [46,47]. The space of 230 nm among adjacent nanoflakes would provide accessible sites for soot combustion (Fig. S1d) as Sarli et al. reported, where the highly dispersed catalysts on the substrates surface would provide more reaction sites for soot [33]. Despite the external points of specimen D is less than that of C, their activities towards soot oxidation aftermentioned are equal because of the same amount of potassium stabilized in the form of composite oxides [28–30]. TEM analysis was employed to investigate the structure and elements distribution of the active components on a more precise level, which is displayed in Fig. 5 . Sample A was absent because the active component was too difficult to strip. The other three specimens were ultrasonically treated for 40–80 min before observation. More information can be got besides the homologous morphologies as observed in SEM. Different from the phase identification in XRD section, K1.33Mn8O16 could be detected from the FFT patterns in Fig. 5. The d values, 2.45 Å and 1.23 Å, correspond to (400) and (800) facets of K1.33Mn8O16 and show regular features [50,51]. The skeletons framed in yellow are likely birnessite MnO2 while the flakes are K1.33Mn8O16, of which the majority is birnessite MnO2 as XRD results. The line scannings and EDS spectra under STEM model in the Fig. S2 sustain that K/Mn approximates 1.33:8 and sample C contains the highest content of K, up to 7.57 at. %. The EDS of blue (B-1) and red (B-2) frames in C show K enrichment in the nanoflowers. It is interesting to find that potassium can be stabilized until 700 °C (3.01 at. %). Potassium species have been numerously reported to accelerate soot oxidation remarkably via wetting soot thereby adding the contact points [30,52]. However, it remains a challenge to stabilize potassium species due to sublimation even at middle temperature region. Catalysts containing potassium usually deactivate after activity evolutions, especially in humid conditions [30,34,53]. It has been proved effective to improve thermal stability of potassium species in the form of composite oxides, such as silicates, manganeses and ferrites [29,54,55]. In C and D, the higher K/Mn or K/Ni ratio implies the composite oxides contain K, Mn and Ni. Furthermore, in Fig. S2c, the line scannings show high concentrations of Ni in the nanoflakes as a result of structure consistency between NiO and birnessite MnO2 [12]. The strong interaction induced from nickel dopants may create oxygen vacancies in the lattice matrix and stabilize potassium species. 3.3 Surface and redox properties X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy is useful in detecting the valence state and abundance of surface elements, which are vital to soot oxidation [56]. As the full spectra in Fig. 6 a displays, specified elements including O, K, Mn and Ni could be identified after calibration using C 1 s peak. The patterns of K 2p spectra in Fig. 6b show the same trend as that of EDS results, and the atomic ratios of K/(K + Mn + Ni) in Table 1 are 0.125, 0.168, 0.210, and 0.198, respectively. This ratio in D seems contrary to that of EDS, possibly due to the strong substrate effect in EDS. In other words, K can be effectively stabilized until 700 °C in the form of composite oxides [26,30]. The deconvoluted O 1 s spectra in Fig. 6c show three oxygen species, i. e. hydroxyl oxygen (Oh, 532.4 eV), active surface oxygen (Oa, 531.0 eV) and lattice oxygen (Ol, 529.5 eV). The quantified results are listed in Table 2 [14,57]. It has been reported that Oh and Oa including OH, O2 − and O2 2- are highly active toward soot oxidation, and these species on sample C, D are the most abundant [57]. On the other hand, the Mn 2p spectra in Fig. 6d and deconvolution results in Table 3 imply more Mn4+ in B and C, which reach 34.8% and 25.4%. And this phenomenon would explain the higher binding energies of Mn in these two specimens. Mn4+ has been proved excellent redox properties in various redox reactions. However, the content of Mn4+ in D is reduced possibly due to thermal decomposition at higher temperature [23]. The nonnegligible Auger effect of Ni was also considered in the deconvolution [58]. Finally, the Ni 2p spectra are given in Fig. 6e, and Table 4 lists the percentages of Ni3+ [59]. Less Ni3+ is detected in D with more Mn2+ and Mn3+ due to likely further interphase reactions between MnO2 and Ni substrate, as evidenced by increased NiO in XRD and Raman results. K+ dopant also accounts for this phenomenon for keeping electric neutrality. So, it can be deduced better redox performance on C and D, as a result of abundant K+ and surface oxygen species (Oh and Oa). The H2-TPR patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 with the quantified results listed in Table S1. For sample A, B and C, peak α can be ascribed to the reduction of birnessite MnO2 while peak β is the reduction of large size NiMnO3, Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 and NiO, as supported by XRD and Fig. 1f. For soot oxidation, the reduction of peak α will be more important. Peak α in sample A, B and C gradually shift to lower temperature with the enlarged peak areas due to different K+ concentrations listed in Table 1. K+ will promote the reduction at lower temperature and will improve the reduction degree [14]. In addition, peak α of sample D shifts to 320 °C because of calcination at 700 °C. The flowerlike birnessite MnO2 (Fig. 4d) collapses, and reacts with Ni substrate into larger nanobelts (Fig. 4e), which can be only reduced at higher temperature and consume more H2. Hence, sample C will show better catalytic performance on soot oxidation. 3.4 Catalytic performance 3.4.1 Soot oxidation Soot oxidation patterns are shown in Fig. 8 and the indicators are listed in Table 5 . The maximum error bar of 5.5 °C shows good repeatability and reliability of the soot combustion evaluation system. Combustion of pure soot will only initiate over 480 °C and hydrothermal treated Ni foam can decrease the T50 from average 576 °C to 515 °C. The as prepared catalysts would effectively accelerate soot oxidation and improve CO2 selectivity from 55.2% (pure soot) to 100%. Comparing A, B and C, more active components and more excellent performance will be achieved with higher hydrothermal temperature. In the fresh catalysts, the about 230 nm macroporous space is of great concern for soot oxidation, which is a classical gas-solid-solid triphase reaction [13,33]. As listed in Table 5, the combustion regions (T90-T10) are 227, 196, 178 and 119 °C respectively for the four specimens. Sample B displays the lowest ignition temperature of 299 °C (within the temperature region of diesel exhaust). And this is possibly due to abundant active surface oxygen species (Oa) and accessible reaction points [4,60]. C shows preferable capability compared to A and B because of hierarchical pore structure and more potassium. It has been reported K+ would activate gas O2 and then oxygen species spillover to soot surface, forming (CO) intermediates and ketene species [30,52,54,55]. Besides, K+ could be stabilized in the [MnO6] layer of birnessite MnO2, and nickel dopants diminish the interlayer spacing, which enhance the KO bonds and then inhabit the random mobilization of K+ [29]. K+ doped in the bulk rather than supported solely on surface has been reported to promote soot oxidation remarkably [26]. The nickel dopants may also induce more abundant oxygen vacancies benefiting for oxygen activation as well as oxygen species spillover [61]. An interesting phenomenon is that the T50 of sample D is 423 °C, very close to that of C. It should be noticed the nanobelts in D are smoother with fewer accessible contact points for soot particulates but considerable amount of K+ like that of sample C could be maintained in birnessite MnO2 composites. Furthermore, oxygen vacancies induced by nickel dopants and the strong interaction between birnessite MnO2 and Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 advances gas oxygen activation despite larger crystal sizes. Table S2 lists under loose contact mode the T50 of sample C and those reported in literature using Printex U as model soot [16,18,22,29,62]. Compared with pure Mn3O4 [22], it is obvious that K-promoted manganeses can accelerate soot oxidation at much lower temperature. In addition, the difference on oxygen concentrations (10 vol. % and 20 vol. %) would not affect soot combustion visibly, but NO greatly accelerates soot oxidation via NO2 routes on K2Mn4O8 and birnessite as Feng and A. Bueno-López et al. described [16,29]. Even so, sample C shows better activity compared with those reported catalysts. 3.4.2 Moisture effect Soot catalytic oxidation was also evaluated via bubbling 6 vol. % water vapor into the influent gas. The patterns are shown in Fig. 9 with T10, T50, T90 and S C O 2 m listed in Table 6 . Distinct effect can be observed, where B, C and D are promoted but A is postponed. T50 of the former three specimens is reduced to 420, 405 and 400 °C yet delayed to 496 °C for A. This delay might be due to low K+ content or highly dispersion state in A because only clusters of K+ compounds are active towards soot oxidation [52]. CO2 selectivity is 99.6% for sample C but decreases to 95.6% and 98.0% for B and D. H2O has been reported to advance soot oxidation via water shift reaction (C+H2O→CO+H2) and wetting soot like K species [63–67]. This may explain the slightly lower CO2 selectivity. Furthermore, it seems to be a synergistic effect between H2O and K since the higher the K content is, the lower T50 is. Nagai and his coworkers found that potassium would promote H2O dissociation [68]. Chen and Edwards et al. also reported that OH from the dissociation of H2O may oxidize the active surface carbon species of soot particulates effectively [52,69]. 3.4.3 Reusability of sample C Fig. 10 a shows the five cyclic T50 of sample C under 20 vol. % O2 and 20 vol. % O2+6 vol. % H2O test conditions. It can be found the T50 under 20 vol. % O2 condition only improves by at most 6 °C while under humid condition it also keeps unchanged. Besides, Fig. 10b shows no phase transformation during the tests and the ratios of NiO/Ni are not increased, implying this catalyst good cycle stability. Fig. 10c and d display that even though the birnessite MnO2 coating is a bit thicker after repeated tests, the coating integrity and macroporous structures are unchanged. Moreover, it is important that K+ could be effectively stabilized. EDS results show that the K/Mn ratios after the cycles are 0.134 and 0.138 respectively, a bit lower than that in K1.33Mn8O16 (0.166), proving the specimen good stability especially under humid conditions [17,30]. In references, supported alkali species evaporate or dissolute seriously after reusability tests but potassium doped in the bulk would be more stable [14,60]. The NiMnO3 interphase and nickel dopants would be the main factors intensifying stability and enhancing KO bonds, thus endowing the catalyst with stable activity. 3.5 Adherence test Fig. 11 displays the morphology and soot oxidation pattern of C after adherence test. In Fig. 11a, the complete birnessite MnO2 layer is still tightly adhered onto Ni foam even though the nanoflakes are partly destroyed. The mean weight loss of birnessite MnO2 coating during three parallel tests is 0.45 ± 0.11 wt. %. The loss may result from fracture of nanoflakes and partly potassium dissolution in water. This loss is normal for a monolithic catalyst [34]. Fewer contact points are thus available for soot particulates, but the performance is still accessible [70]. As shown in Fig. 11b, T10, T50 and T90 are 369, 451 and 509 °C respectively. Here, the compact interphase NiMnO3 would intensify the nanoflakes against exfoliation. In addition, interphase NiMnO3 may also remedy the activity via synergistic reactions with birnessite MnO2 since the contact change between soot and NiMnO3 becomes higher [71,72]. Moreover, despite H2O molecules may diffuse into the interlayer space of birnessite MnO2 during ultrasonic test, the performance here implies that nickel dopants and [MnO6] layers enhance KO bonds against water encroachments [14]. 3.6 Mechanism discussion In our previous work, the synthesis of MnO2 could be accelerated based on the redox reactions between reactants via an acid-free hydrothermal route, where CeMn nanocomposites were prepared via reactions between [MnO4]− and Ce3+ [18]. And here, we prepared monolithic birnessite MnO2 coating on Ni foam following the same principle. The contents of active constituents in sample A (2.01 wt. %), B (4.30 wt. %), C and D (9.61 wt. %), which are synthesized at 100, 120 and 160 °C separately, show positive correlation with temperature. As Scheme 1 describes, the redox reactions between KMnO4 and smooth Ni foam would generate birnessite MnO2 nanoflakes, NiO and compact NiMnO3 interphase particles. NiMnO3 inhabits parallel birnessite MnO2 nanoflakes from transforming into randomly oriented nanorods during calcination and strengths the coating adherence. The nanoflakes, including birnessite MnO2 and K1.33Mn8O16, could be identified in HRTEM, with Ni dopants mostly as Ni3+. These species may efficaciously activate O2 and enhance redox properties, as H2-TPR patterns in Fig. 7 display. Furthermore, nickel ions and K+ would generate many oxygen vacancies in the matrix of birnessite MnO2 and facilitate lattice oxygen transferring to surface and promote soot oxidation as references reported [22,73]. For soot oxidation, three feasible strategies can improve the catalytic performance. They are adding accessible points for soot particulates, enhancing redox property of the catalysts and introducing alkali elements. As Scheme 1 and Fig. S1d illustrate, the hierarchical morphology structure of the monolithic catalysts will provide numerous contact points capturing soot [33]. Besides, the layer structure of birnessite advances O2 diffusion, activation and soot oxidation. Hence, B and C display superior performance compared to A. In addition, K+ in C is the most abundant, which has been reported to activate O2 forming active oxygen species or tune the electron distribution states of soot particulates [29,52,64]. The active oxygen species may spillover to electropositive soot surface and oxidize soot forming CO or ketone intermediates. These intermediates then diffuse into the layers of birnessite MnO2 for deep oxidation. Hence, C shows the highest activity and CO2 selectivity toward soot oxidation. Li et al. reported that the Co3O4 nanowires on Ni foams provided lots of sites capturing soot particles while the potassium stabilized in the composites promoted performance in consecutive soot combustion tests [14]. D displayed performance just next to C catalyst in spite of its smoother nanobelts with minor active points. Namely, the importance of K+ content in D exceeds contact points and this may be supported by the fact that a thick layer of soot covers the surface, as Fig. S1d displays. Atribak et al. synthesized birnessite and cryptomelane and found birnessite more active toward total soot oxidation despite much smaller surface areas or pore volumes [29]. Soot oxidation on these catalysts is sensitive to the surface structure such as element distribution and valence state. It is interesting that K+ can exist in the form of composites until 700 °C against thermal volatilization or moisture dissolution [15]. This may be mainly ascribed to the nickel dopants including Ni2+ or Ni3+. Furthermore, K+ and nickel dopants in the nanoflowers or nanobelts would also induce oxygen vacancies as well as high valent manganese ions, thus accelerating lattice oxygen delivery and soot oxidation [22,73]. For a monolithic purification catalyst, the cohesion of active components layer is vital to duration. NiMnO3 interphase tightly combines birnessite MnO2 coating with Ni foam. Compared with reported monolithic catalyst, the ultrasonic treatment in water bath proves C excellent coherence [34]. Despite a small portion of the nanoflakes were broken during the test, this specimen still showed good activity. And this again proves soot oxidation is surface sensitivity. The compact NiMnO3 interphase plays a role as effective washcoating against exfoliation with nickel dopants improving thermal stability and water resistance of K+. 4 Conclusions Different from the traditional coating routes manufacturing DPFs, we developed a facile hydrothermal method to synthesize monolithic birnessite MnO2 coating on three-dimensional Ni foams based on the redox reactions between reactants. The flowerlike MnO2 layers are tightly adhered on Ni foam substrate via compact NiMnO3 or Ni6.8Mn0.6O8 interphases. The hierarchical structure of Ni foam would facilitate soot delivery while the crosslinked nanoflowers add contact points. The sample prepared at 160 °C shows the best catalytic performance and good reusability because of abundant potassium, surface active oxygen (Oh and Oa), Mn4+ and Ni3+. These species together improve the redox properties of catalyst C. K+ effectively activates O2 and accelerates soot oxidation via (CO) or ketene intermediates at much lower temperature. Furthermore, not only strengthen KO bond thereby preventing thermal evaporation or water dissolution, nickel dopants ameliorate performance by inducing more oxygen vacancies. NiMnO3 interphase is also effective to enhance the coherence states against exfoliation. The strategy can be also employed to synthesize other monolithic catalysts without using binders. Sample C might be a promising monolith purificating real diesel exhaust and relevant work is on the way. coredata.dc:description: The soot particulates emitted from diesel engines have been ultimately evidenced cancerogenic and successive rigorous emission legislations have been approved in many countries. Monolithic metal-based purification materials are able to tackle the harsh working conditions. Hence, monolithic birnessite MnO2/Ni foam catalysts were facilely synthesized via a hydrothermal route and characterized by XRD, Raman spectroscopy, SEM, HRSTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, et al. The coating weights are in proportion to hydrothermal temperatures. And the catalyst synthesized at 160 °C displays the lowest T50 (418 °C) with the coating exfoliation rates of only 0.45 ± 0.11 wt. %. Porous Ni substrates tightly covered with a layer of crosslinked flowerlike birnessite MnO2 coating would provide many available sites capturing soot particulates. The interphase NiMnO3 between nanoflowers and Ni substrate could intensify nanoflowers against exfoliation, and inhibit transformation into disordered nanorods. Potassium in the birnessite may activate gas O2 effectively forming active oxygen species and improve the redox properties. Moreover, nickel dopants inhibit K+ thermal evaporation and water dissolution via strengthening KO bonds, thus endowing good reusability. This candidate is likely a promising monolithic catalyst purifying the real diesel exhaust. And the method will be employed to synthesize novel monolithic metallic catalysts for other catalytic applications.
coredata.dc:title: Interphase strengthening birnessite MnO2 coating on three-dimensional Ni foam for soot removal
